10.23.3.2 - Applicant Suitability Prescreening and Fingerprint Check
a.
- Removed the word “Appointee” from the title. PS does not prescreen appointees - appointees are prescreened, approved applicants. b.

Removed sentence that states “prescreening investigative techniques vary depending on the subject’s position risk level.” The prescreen process is the same for all applicants regardless of the risk level.

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
All Divisions and Functions
for Employment and Operations
page (

) Purpose. This section is to provide the policies, guidelines and requirements for the administration of the Internal Revenue Service’s (IRS) personnel security program relating to the initiation of suitability/security screening investigations. Every position within Treasury/IRS requires that potential employees or incumbent employees undergo a suitability screening and/or in- vestigation conducted by an appropriate government authority based upon sensitivity of the position, and/or need for access to classiﬁed information, requirements of Homeland Security Presidential Directive (HSPD-
) (http:// www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/ﬁles/omb/memoranda/fy
/m
pdf). (

) The investigative requirements shall be consistent with the guidance provided by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). Background investigations, conducted for suitability or security determination purposes constitute the ﬁrst step in the process of ensuring the highest standards of honesty, integrity, security among IRS employees, enabling the IRS to carry out its mission and ensure the integrity of its employees. Suitability reﬂects the standards for employment with the Government in general, and the IRS in particular, reference to a person’s character, reputation and overall ﬁtness. (
) Audience. This IRM is for all IRS Divisions and functions. (
) Policy Owner. Personnel Security (PS, Employment, Talent, and Security (
) Program Owner. PS is responsible for overseeing the Personnel Security Program and providing policy and procedures related to Personnel Security matters. (

by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). Background investigations, conducted for suitability or security determination purposes constitute the ﬁrst step in the process of ensuring the highest standards of honesty, integrity, and security among IRS employees, enabling the IRS to carry out its mission and ensure the integrity of its employees. Suitability reﬂects the standards required for employment with the Government in general, and the IRS in particular, with reference to a person’s character, reputation and overall ﬁtness.

Prescreening investigative steps vary depending on the subject’s position risk level. Steps may include: Federal Bureau of (FBI) ﬁngerprint check, credit check, Automated Labor and Employee Tracking System (ALERTS) check, federal tax compliance check, check, review of required security forms, and a check to determine if an existing prior investigation can be used in lieu of requesting a new tion. ) Employment Offices must employ every reasonable means available to obtain suitability information prior to the applicant’s Enter on Duty (EOD) date. This applies to all applicants including: a. Career appointments b. Career-conditional appointments c. Temporary appointments

) In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, all Treasury/IRS and employees, including contractor employees, for whom a credit check is initiated, will be notiﬁed in writing that credit reports may be obtained for ployment purposes. Written consent must be obtained prior to any such being procured. Individuals must be notiﬁed promptly if information in their credit report may result in any unfavorable action, such as denial of a clearance, employment, or access authorization. ) Every IRS position, including those of contractors, must be designated with suitability risk or national security sensitivity level. All employees who position, and all contractors who perform services in a like position, must personnel security/suitability standards commensurate with the position risk/ sensitivity level of the position or services performed and are subject to personnel security background investigation requirements. a. Public Trust positions are designated at the High or Moderate risk Suitability risk levels commensurate with public trust responsibilities attributes of the position as they relate to the efficiency of the service, and as described in Title
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part

b. National Security positions are designated at the Special-Sensitive, Critical-Sensitive, or Noncritical-Sensitive sensitivity level. National Security sensitivity levels commensurate with the potential adverse impact upon the National Security that the incumbent could affect, as described in
CFR Part

A complete list of IRS position descriptions and position risk designations is available at http://hco.web.irs.gov/posclass/
position risk designations is available at http://hco.web.irs.gov/posclass/ positiondesc/index.html. Positions that are intermittent, seasonal, per diem, or temporary, not to exceed a total of

). The IRS, however, must conduct certain checks as it deems appropriate to ensure the suitability of the person. Please see chart below.
Personnel Security/Suitability for Employment and Personnel Security Operations 10.23.3
Security Operations
) OPM establishes the level of investigation required for each position risk nation. In FY

, the OPM implemented the following Federal Tiers Standards (FIN) issued by the Suitability and Security Executive Agents. standards are used to determine eligibility for logical and physical access, ability for U.S. Government employment, ﬁtness to perform work for, or on behalf of U.S. Government as a contract employee, and eligibility for classiﬁed information or to hold a sensitive position. (
) The standards consist of ﬁve tiers with an Expandable Focused (EFI) model at each tier as shown below: • Tier
(investigation for positions designated as low risk • Tier
(Investigation for non-sensitive positions designated as risk-public trust positions) • Tier
(investigation for national security positions designated as critical sensitive and/or requiring access to Conﬁdential or Secret information) • Tier
(investigation for high risk-public trust positions) • Tier
(investigation for national security positions - top secret, compartmented information, critical sensitive and special sensitive) (
) The minimum investigative requirements for IRS public trust positions as ommended by the Department of the Treasury and OPM are: a. Tier
- Moderate Risk b. Tier
- High Risk (

) Personnel in Information Technology (IT) positions with ‘Privileged Access’ IRS “sensitive” IT systems must be designated at the High-risk level and Level for requisite completed background investigation must be favorably adjudicated Access prior to obtaining privileged access. (

) “Privileged Access” is deﬁned as administrator or root access to DS, and IRSNET domains (for example, IBM and application access Individual Master File [IMF]; Business Master File [BMF]; Customer Account Data Engine, [CADE/CADE

], Redesigned Revenue Accounting System Integrated Financial System [IFS] and Corporate Files on Line [CFOL] that contain highly sensitive, critical information. Individuals in such positions example, system administrator, data base administrator, network with this level of access have major program responsibilities/duties and au- thorities that are critical to the IRS mission; and if information is it could potentially cause exceptionally serious damage to sensitive IT and to the national ﬁnancial market. (
) Personnel in positions designated as either High or Moderate risk are to reinvestigation no later than

years from the date of completion of their original investigation and every ﬁve years thereafter, unless the following occurs: a. prior to the next required reinvestigation, a separate investigation is conducted to determine a person’s eligibility (or continued eligibility) access to classiﬁed information or to hold a sensitive position. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
The minimum investigative requirements for IRS public trust positions as ommended by the Department of the Treasury and OPM are:

Personnel b. a change in risk level and that investigation meets or exceeds the re- quirements for a public trust reinvestigation, a new public trust reinvestigation is not required. Such a completed investigation restarts the cycle for a public trust reinvestigation for that person. (
) The minimum reinvestigation required is at least a (Tier

) investigation. Personnel in Low Risk positions are not subject to reinvestigation while they remain in a Low Risk position. There is currently no government-wide ment to conduct reinvestigations of employees in low-risk, non-sensitive positions. (

) If there is a change in position risk or sensitivity level, i.e., an employee moving to a position at a higher risk or sensitivity level than the position he she currently occupies, the following must occur: a. Employee must meet the investigative requirements of the position risk designation of the new position. b. Any upgrade in the investigation required for the new risk level should initiated within
calendar days of the effective date of the new designation. (

) For an individual moving into a Critical-Sensitive or Special-Sensitive the investigation must be completed pre-appointment. Other than for Critical- Sensitive or Special-Sensitive levels, if the position risk or sensitivity of an incumbent’s position is increased due to an accretion of duties and responsi- bilities, the incumbent may remain in the position, but the investigation by the higher risk/sensitivity level shall be initiated within
working days of the effective date of the new position designation. (
) When an employee moves from a public trust position and who previously completed the Standard Form (SF)

P, Questionnaire for Public Trust Positions, (and was investigated for that purpose) is subsequently to require a security clearance to perform assigned duties, the following shall be done: a. The public trust position designation must be re-designated to the priate national security designation level, commensurate with the security clearance level, i.e., Top Secret, Secret or Conﬁdential. b. The employee shall complete a SF

, Questionnaire for National Security Positions, and meet the necessary security clearance tive criteria. c. Managers must immediately initiate a personnel action to reassign employees to a national security Standard Position Description. Con- versely, if national security duties/responsibilities are no longer the position’s trust level then reverts to a public trust risk designation. (

) For an applicant occupying a position designated as a sensitive national security position (non-critical sensitive, critical sensitive, special sensitive), position will be ﬁlled only by an individual for whom the requisite background investigation has been completed satisfactorily prior to appointment. (
) For individuals occupying national security positions, the sensitivity/risk and minimum required investigations are: a. Special Sensitive (level

The exception will be documented in the case ﬁle and reviewed for concurrence by the Associate Director, PS. (
) Investigations are used to determine suitability for employment in positions in the competitive service, excepted service and the Senior Executive Service. (
) In accordance with the Treasury Security Manual, (chapter
, section
), employees appointed to any Treasury/bureau position are subject to a ity investigation (
) upon initial appointment to the Federal service and (
) upon reappointment after a break in service of

or more months. may also be subjected to investigation for access to national security tion prior to or immediately following entrance-on-duty. Current Federal employees appointed to Treasury/IRS positions may be subjected to further investigation if the position to which they are being appointed carries a risk designation than that for which they were previously investigated. In general, the type of investigation to be requested is based on the position’s sensitivity or risk level designation. (

) PS will accept background investigations and adjudications conducted by federal agencies unless it is determined that the background investigation or adjudication does not sufficiently address the Federal Investigative Standards (FIS) used by PS in determining suitability. (

) Prior completed background investigations and ﬁnal favorable adjudications be accepted for a suitability determination when: a. The investigation meets or exceeds the requirements for the risk desig- nation of the position to be ﬁlled; b. There has been no break in service of more than
months; c. The favorable adjudication was based on criteria set forth in
CFR

d. The individual must have served continuously for at least one year in position where they were favorably adjudicated; and e. there must be no new adverse information obtained in connection with the individual’s appointment that calls into question his/her suitability under
CFR

) Reciprocity does not need to be accepted if the issues in the prior are not compatible with the core duties of the new position. a. PS will search OPM’s investigative database to determine if reciprocity a prior investigation applies when: Internal Revenue Manual

The Employment Office (EO) indicates that the applicant requires a completed background investigation b. The results of the reciprocity search will automatically populate into PS’ Automated Background Investigation System (ABIS). The EO will determine if the completed investigation can be reciprocally accepted based on whether the investigation meets or exceeds the position risk/ sensitivity level and if there is no break in service of no more than

months. (
) When feasible, all background investigations shall be completed and decisions made within an appointee’s ﬁrst year of service. (

) The scope and coverage area of the investigation is determined by the nated position risk/sensitivity level. The investigation is designed to reveal pertinent facts, past and present, about the character, honesty, reputation, etc., of the applicant or employee. Upon completion of the ﬁnal vestigation, a suitability decision is made by PS after reviewing the results the required background investigation. (
) If the subject of an investigation separates or is no longer being considered appointment, the investigation must be discontinued. (

) For appointees with less than one current continuous year of service, the Associate Director, Personnel Security, has delegated authority to make ability determinations and propose suitability actions under
CFR Part
, except for those cases that must be referred to the OPM. (See
CFR

CFR Part

) year probationary period and on any case under its authority as deemed necessary (

) The suitability adjudication procedures for appointees (a person who has entered on duty and is in the ﬁrst year of a subject-to-investigation appoint- ment) with less than one current continuous year of service require that adjudications be made with reference to the person’s: a. Basic suitability for Federal employment; b. Suitability for employment in a speciﬁc position in terms of the position risk designation; and c. Suitability for employment in a speciﬁc position in terms of the character or conduct. (
) The suitability adjudication determination must be based on criteria listed in accordance with the OPM Suitability Processing Handbook.
When feasible, all background investigations shall be completed and suitability decisions made within an appointee’s ﬁrst year of service.

a. Basic suitability for Federal employment; b. Suitability for employment in a speciﬁc position in terms of the position risk designation; and c. Suitability for employment in a speciﬁc position in terms of the person’s character or conduct.
The suitability adjudication determination must be based on criteria listed in accordance with the OPM Suitability Processing Handbook.

) As outlined in
CFR

, OPM has retained jurisdiction for suitability in all competitive service cases involving the issues listed below. OPM has delegated certain aspects of these authorities to agencies, but and retains overall responsibility: a. Evidence of material, intentional false statements, deception, or fraud examination or appointment, including SES career appointments; b. Refusal to furnish testimony; c. Statutory or regulatory bar; (

CFR
, is not a suitability action even if it is based on reasons set in

) Executive Order
was amended to establish the roles and ties of the NBIB in September

The NBIB is established within the with responsibility for conducting effective, efficient, and secure personnel background investigations pursuant to law, rule, regulation, or executive The NBIB will be the primary service provider of government-wide investigations for the Federal government with the mission of delivering ground investigations to ensure the integrity and trustworthiness of the workforce. (
) The IRS has delegated authority from OPM to impose agency-speciﬁc debarment of applicants and appointees from IRS covered positions under Title,

) The IRS must base its suitability determination on the presence or one or more speciﬁc factors. Some of the speciﬁc factors that must be ered as a basis for ﬁnding a person unsuitable and taking a suitability are: a. Misconduct or negligence in employment b. Criminal or dishonest conduct c. Alcohol abuse; and illegal drugs (

) The IRS must also consider additional considerations to the extent the its sole discretion, deems any of the pertinent to the individual case. Some the additional considerations include: a. the nature of the position for which the person is applying or in which person is employed b. seriousness/recency of the conduct; circumstances of the conduct c. person’s age when conduct occurred (

The QAS tablishes federal guidelines for assessing the quality of national security and suitability background investigations based on the Federal Investigative Standards (FIS), implemented in December
The establishment of assessment standards will facilitate the measurement and continued ment of investigative quality across the Executive Branch. (

) The QAS are established for background investigations to determine for: a. logical and physical access b. suitability for government employment c. eligibility for access to classiﬁed information and to hold a sensitive position d. ﬁtness to perform work for/or on behalf of the government as a employee (
) The QAS also applies to the background investigations of state, local, tribal and private sectors entities as deﬁned in EO

) The QAS will establish how investigative quality will be deﬁned, measured assessed. The QAS are not designed to determine if or what adjudicative action will be taken, but to support the standardization of background gations which in turn supports uniformity and reciprocity. (

) In January
, the Security and Suitability Executive Agents approved the Quality Assessment Standards for Background Investigations (QAS) which were distributed to federal agencies to be implemented in

The QAS tablishes federal guidelines for assessing the quality of national security and suitability background investigations based on the Federal Investigative Standards (FIS), implemented in December
The establishment of assessment standards will facilitate the measurement and continued ment of investigative quality across the Executive Branch. (

) The QAS are established for background investigations to determine for: a. logical and physical access b. suitability for government employment c. eligibility for access to classiﬁed information and to hold a sensitive position d. ﬁtness to perform work for/or on behalf of the government as a employee (
) The QAS also applies to the background investigations of state, local, tribal and private sectors entities as deﬁned in EO

) The QAS will establish how investigative quality will be deﬁned, measured assessed. The QAS are not designed to determine if or what adjudicative action will be taken, but to support the standardization of background gations which in turn supports uniformity and reciprocity. (
) The QAS are based on four category assessments that characterizes the in- vestigation as:
Complete - all coverage is obtained and all issues are resolved
Justiﬁed – component requirement is missing but an adequate tion is present
Incomplete – component requirement is missing and no adequate nation
Insufficient – known issues not resolved and/or excessively poor reporting present Note: An investigation can be both incomplete and insufficient.

The QAS es- tablishes federal guidelines for assessing the quality of national security and suitability background investigations based on the Federal Investigative Standards (FIS), implemented in December

The establishment of quality assessment standards will facilitate the measurement and continued improve- ment of investigative quality across the Executive Branch. The QAS are established for background investigations to determine eligibility for:
10.23.3.14 (05-09-2019) Quality Assessment Standards
Complete
all coverage is obtained and all issues are resolved Justiﬁed – component requirement is missing but an adequate explana
tion is present Incomplete – component requirement is missing and no adequate expla
nation Insufficient – known issues not resolved and/or excessively poor reporting present
Note: An investigation can be both incomplete and insufficient.

When the quality of an investigation is evaluated, it will be assigned one of the four assessment categories outlined above. The only exceptions are the inves- tigations that are assessed as both incomplete and insufficient.

To ensure independence of the adjudication and referral process and to eliminate any appearance of a conﬂict of interest in the handling of investiga- tive reports conducted on employees of PS and the HCO Executives to whom PS directly reports, the following procedures shall be affected:

All such completed reports of investigation conducted for suitability or security purposes will be made available either electronically or in hard copy to the Office of Security Programs (OSP), Department of the Treasury by OPM. Treasury OSP adjudicates the case for suitability and clearance as implemented in the common adjudicative standards set forth by the
CFR
and

Treasury OSP sends an email notiﬁcation regarding the completion of investigation to Associate Director, PS. Upon notiﬁcation from Treasury, PS updates the Automated Background Investigation System (ABIS) and the Personnel Investigations System (PIPS)/Clearance Veriﬁcation System (CVS) with security clearance and investigative information. PS briefs IRS employees and HCO Executive Team members whose cases are favorably adjudicated for access to classiﬁed information. PS provides Treasury OSP a copy of the signed SF-

for recordation purposes. PS advises Treasury OSP of any change in status of PS employees or contractors. The ﬁnal determination/adjudication will be referred to Labor Relations only when appropriate action is recommended. Treasury OSP will maintain a copy of the report of investigation and complete the Form
(C) or TD F
PS will make post-investigation suitability determinations on employees with less than one current continuous year of service, using the speciﬁc factors contained in
CFR

(b). The PS adjudicators, trained under OPM suit- ability guidelines, will make determinations based on a person’s character and/or conduct that may have an impact on the integrity or efficiency of the service.
Personnel (
) When an agency-initiated suitability action is taken against an appointee less than one current continuous year of service, PS or OPM prepares a Notice of Proposed Action (
CFR

). a. PS must notify the appointee (hereinafter, the ″respondent″) in writing the proposed action, the charges against the respondent, and the ability to request a review of the materials supporting the charges. notice must outline the speciﬁc reasons for the proposed action and the individual’s right to respond to the notice in writing. The notice also inform the respondent of the time limit for the answer; b. The notice must inform the respondent that he or she may be repre- sented by a representative of the respondent’s choice and that if the respondent wishes to have such a representative, the respondent designate the representative in writing; c. The agency must serve the notice of proposed action by mail or hand delivery no less than

days prior to the effective date of the action. The notice must be served to the respondent’s last known residence or duty station; and d. If respondent is employed in a position covered by this part when the notice is served, the respondent may remain in a pay status during notice period. (
) Respondent’s answers to the Notice of Proposed Action: a. The respondent may submit a written response, including affidavits, other written evidence, up to
days of your receipt of notice; and b. The respondent may be represented by a representative of choice if ignated in writing. (
) Agency’s decision (
CFR
): a. The decision regarding the ﬁnal action must be in writing, be dated, inform the respondent of the reasons for the decision and that an vorable decision may be appealed in accordance with
CFR Part and b. If the decision requires removal, the employing agency must remove appointee from the rolls within
workdays of the agency’s decision. (

) When OPM or an agency acting under delegated authority takes a action against a person, that person may appeal the action to the Merit Systems Protection Board (hereinafter “Board”), in accordance with
CFR Subpart E. (

) If the Board remands the case to OPM or the Agency for review, OPM or Agency will determine whether the action taken is appropriate based on the sustained charges, and the determination will be ﬁnal without any further appeal to the Board. (
) The procedures for ﬁling an appeal with the Board can be found here.

a. PS must notify the appointee (hereinafter, the ″respondent″) in writing of the proposed action, the charges against the respondent, and the avail- ability to request a review of the materials supporting the charges. The notice must outline the speciﬁc reasons for the proposed action and the individual’s right to respond to the notice in writing. The notice must also inform the respondent of the time limit for the answer; b. The notice must inform the respondent that he or she may be repre- sented by a representative of the respondent’s choice and that if the respondent wishes to have such a representative, the respondent must designate the representative in writing; c. The agency must serve the notice of proposed action by mail or hand delivery no less than

days prior to the effective date of the proposed action. The notice must be served to the respondent’s last known residence or duty station; and d. If respondent is employed in a position covered by this part when the notice is served, the respondent may remain in a pay status during the notice period.
If the decision requires removal, the employing agency must remove the appointee from the rolls within 5 workdays of the agency’s decision.

) In accordance with Treasury Security Manual, TD P
, Chapter I,

, “Personnel Security Operations,” the Service will establish and maintain Files personnel security ﬁle for employees in the following positions: a. national security positions; b. moderate and high-risk public trust positions; and c. low-risk/non-sensitive positions where unfavorable or derogatory tion has been developed or received, unless the ﬁle is maintained by OPM. (
) All contractors are subject to the same requirements as Treasury/IRS employees with a ﬁle maintained for contractor personnel covered by the sions of Chapter II, Section
, of TD P
or who require a background investigation to meet the requirements of Homeland Security Presidential Directive (HSPD-

) The Service will not maintain a ﬁle on a contract employee granted access classiﬁed information under the National Industrial Security Program unless there is a requirement for additional investigation relating to access Treasury/IRS facilities or automated information systems or access to information not covered under the NISP. (

) Regarding favorable investigations on employees or contractor personnel in low or moderate risk positions, the Service will retain pertinent investigative data only, such as adverse derogatory information. (
) All personnel security ﬁles are under the control of the Associate Director, (
) In accordance with TD P
, Chapter I, Section

, when an employee transfers from the Treasury Agency office to a bureau or from one bureau another, the complete personnel security ﬁle or a copy of it must be and from the personnel security office of the losing bureau to the personnel office of the gaining bureau. Exception: when the ﬁle of an IRS employee contains tax information, the tax information is not transferred outside the (

) Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) in background investigations, and operations shall be carefully safeguarded to protect the interests of the individual and the Service, pursuant to requirements of the Privacy Act. Unless classiﬁed at a higher level, personnel security information must be afforded the same degree of protection as material identiﬁed as ″Controlled Unclassiﬁed Information″ and must be used only for authorized official purposes. When not in use, personnel security information must be stored General Services Administration approved security container or in an secure area. All electronic records shall be safeguarded in accordance with IRM
) Reports containing classiﬁed information must be protected in accordance Executive Order
, Classiﬁed National Security Information and priate Treasury regulations. (
) Personnel security investigation information requested by the subject of an vestigation will be processed according to established procedures under (

) Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) in background investigations, records, and operations shall be carefully safeguarded to protect the interests of both the individual and the Service, pursuant to requirements of the Privacy Act. Information that adversely reﬂects on a person’s character, integrity or reliability that suggests that their ability to safeguard sensitive information may be impaired, or that their employment and national security eligibility is not in the best interest of Treasury/IRS. An official examination of facts or other pertinent information that covers a deﬁned period of normally no more than

years. The information is compiled from a review of various records, interview with the subject, and interviews with persons who have knowledge of the subject. The information collected must be sufficient to allow an affirmative or negative determination of a person’s eligibility and suitability to work for the Federal Government.

Established within OPM as the primary service provider for conducting effective and efficient back
ground investigations for employment suitability or ﬁtness to perform work for or on behalf of the Federal Government.
A position that (

) involves activities of the Govern- ment that are concerned with the protection of the nation from foreign aggression or espionage, including development of defense plans or policies, intelligence or counter intelligence activities, and related activities concerned with the preservation of the military strength of the United States, and/or (
) requires regular use of, or access to, classiﬁed information.
OPM is an independent Federal agency that works in numerous broad areas to recruit and retain a ﬁrst
rate Federal workforce. One function is to provide investigative services for Federal agencies to use as the basis for employee suitability, con

tractor ﬁtness, and security clearance eligibility across the Federal Government. An investigation that is required every ﬁve years for contractor employees who perform work for or on behalf of the Federal Government and are in positions designated high and moderate risk. Also considered Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) information. Information that is linked or linkable to an individual that must be protected to prevent the possibility of identity theft or invasion of privacy. An organization comprised of security specialists that are engaged in the formulation and application of security policies and procedures involving the trustworthiness and loyalty of persons employed with the Federal Government in sensitive and non

An organization comprised of security specialists that are engaged in the formulation and application of security policies and procedures involving the trustworthiness and loyalty of persons employed with the Federal Government in sensitive and non
sensitive positions.

subparts C and D.

A person born in the U.S. or its territories, or born in a foreign country to U.S. born parents are U.S. citizens by birth.
